ranges.title: Sub-Bass
ranges.description: These very low bass frequencies are felt, rather than heard, as with freeway rumbling or an earthquake. These frequencies give your mix a sense of power, even when they only occur occasionally. However, overemphasizing frequencies in this range will result in a muddy mix.

ranges.title: Bass
ranges.description: Because this range contains the fundamental notes of the rhythm section, any EQ changes will affect the balance of your mix, making it fat or thin. Too much emphasis will make for a boomy mix.

ranges.title: Low-Mids
ranges.description: Boosting the range from 250 Hz to 500 Hz will accent ambience in the studio and will add clarity to bass and lower frequency instruments.

ranges.title: Mids
ranges.description: The range between 500 Hz and 2 kHz can make midrange instruments (guitar, snare, saxophone, etc.) “honky,” and too much boost between 1 kHz and 2 kHz can make your mix sound thin or “tinny.”

ranges.title: Upper-Mids
ranges.description: The attack portion of percussive and rhythm instruments occurs in this range. High mids are also responsible for the projection of midrange instruments.

ranges.title: Presence
ranges.description: This frequency range is partly responsible for the clarity of a mix and provides a measure of control over the perception of distance. If you boost this frequency range, the mix will be perceived as closer to the listener. Attenuating around 5 kHz will make the mix sound further away but also more transparent.

ranges.title: Highs
ranges.description: While this range controls the brilliance and clarity of your mix, boosting it too much can cause some clipping, so keep an eye on your main meter.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: Highpass 20-40 Hz range with 48 dB filter slope. Getting rid of subsonic content here preserves headroom. 24-48 dB slopes work perfectly for such task (keep Q factor set by default 0.71).

ranges.title: Body/Weight
ranges.description: This range is the body and meat of the kick sound. Boost 2-3 dB with wide Q within 90-145 Hz range if more presence is needed. Keep an eye on meters, boosts in this range increase levels quickly so you may want to compensate for it.

ranges.title: Mud/Boxiness
ranges.description: Sweep 145-500 Hz band with Q set high enough to get 6-8 dB of gain resulting in a resonant peak. Tweak the band knob while listening carefully – frequencies that sound most dissonant should be attenuated carefully. Mud mostly resides within 250-350 Hz range.

ranges.title: Knock/Attack
ranges.description: Check 2-4 kHz range for the extra attack. Stay moderate with 2-3 dB bell curve boosts (high shelf and tilt EQs will work nicely as well). Working on this area provides a “bouncing basketball” type of ‘thwack’ tone.

ranges.title: Air/Click
ranges.description: Try boosting 5-8 kHz range with high shelf curve if more presence is needed. Keep watch on the 8-12 kHz band though as boosting there may add hiss. You can find the click sound of the beater up around the 3-8 kHz range, a peaking band works well here.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: Highpass carefully from 100 Hz upwards. 12-24 dB steep highpass filters may be used. Use your ears and choose what sounds best.

ranges.title: Body
ranges.description: This is the central area of sound in most snare drums. Most fundamental characteristics live somewhere inside of this range. Boost 2-3 dB with wide Q within this range to make the snare sound heavier.

ranges.title: Ring
ranges.description: This range is responsible for the all-too-undesirable “ringing” or hollow tone of the snare. Search within 250-600 Hz range for it. Sweep the band with a resonant peak, attenuate unpleasant sounding frequencies with narrow Q cuts.

ranges.title: Bang/Smack
ranges.description: Boost some decibels at 2 kHz for more, boost 2-4 kHz range slightly for extra bite and attack.

ranges.title: Air/Definition
ranges.description: Boosting 4-6 kHz range brings more air. If is still sounds off, boost 7-10 kHz range slightly as that should bring extra definition. The cracking sound made by the stick on the drum head is often around 8000 Hz.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: Highpass carefully from 70 Hz upwards but don’t overdo, as you may thin out the sound too much.

ranges.title: Body/Thump
ranges.description: Boost 100-300 Hz range to add weight. Don’t overdo as boosting too much will sound boomy. While it depends on the actual tuning of the drum, you should be careful while mixing here as too much can make your toms sound muddy, while too little can create a thin tone.

ranges.title: Attack
ranges.description: This is where you’ll find the attack tones from the drumstick hitting the head of the drum itself. Boost 3-4 kHz for extra bite.

ranges.title: Presence/Air
ranges.description: Boost 3-4 dB within 6-9 kHz band to accentuate stick hits. 2-3 dB high shelf boost within 5-12 kHz range will bring extra air and presence.

ranges.title: Low End
ranges.description: Highpass 100-200 Hz to get rid of unnecessary low end.

ranges.title: Gong/Clank/Chink
ranges.description: Highpass up to 400 Hz to get rid of “gong” sounds. Boost 200-300 Hz range slightly for more “chink” but don’t overdo – as it may sound muddy.

ranges.title: Air/Brightness
ranges.description: Sweep from 6 kHz upwards to find the “tsss” part of the sound and boost slightly when done for more air. Attenuating 10 kHz range will reduce harshness while boosting 14-15 kHz will bring more brightness, but be careful as too much can create an extremely shrill tone.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: High-pass to get rid of low-end rumble.

ranges.title: Low End
ranges.description: Boost to fill out the bottom. Cut to reduce boominess and increase clarity. Check with kick.

ranges.title: Fundamental
ranges.description: Boost to increase lower fundamental frequencies. Too muck can sound boomy. A good balance should sound fat and powerful.

ranges.title: Clarity
ranges.description: Boost to improve bass clarity and resonance. Boost to fill out a thin bass.

ranges.title: Attack
ranges.description: Boost to add presence. Boost to accentuate punch/attack.

ranges.title: String Noise
ranges.description: Cut to reduce or add to bring fret/finger/string noise.

ranges.title: Ring
ranges.description: Cut with a thin Q to remove unwanted harmonics. Sometimes all this range can be filtered, not to mask guitar. Too much content here can sound noisy.

ranges.title: Air
ranges.description: Boost to add 'air'. Can make virtual bass sound more natural.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: High-pass to get rid of low-end rumble. Range can change for low tuned guitars.

ranges.title: Low End
ranges.description: Cut to reduce boominess. Too much can sound muddy. Too little can sound thin. Boost in solo to bring back lows.

ranges.title: Punch
ranges.description: Boost for more punch. Cut to reduce overlap with bass. Check together with bass, so that they would merge into each other.

ranges.title: Low Mids
ranges.description: Cut around snare to prevent overlap.

ranges.title: Overtones
ranges.description: Cut to reduce overtones. Boost to increase size.

ranges.title: Crunch
ranges.description: Boost to increase color and crunch. Cut to reduce dullness of guitar.

ranges.title: Attack
ranges.description: Boost to add attack. Cut to clean up hiss in distorted guitars. Check with vocals not to mask it.

ranges.title: Presence
ranges.description: Boost to increase brightness and presence. Cut to make guitar further in the mix.

ranges.title: Harshness
ranges.description: Cut to reduce harshness. Boost to accentuate attack.

ranges.title: Brilliance
ranges.description: Boost to add brilliance.

ranges.title: Presence/Attack/Brightness
ranges.description: Cut or filter to reduce fizz in distorted guitars. Boost to lift acoustic guitar in the mix. Too much may sound harsh and brittle. Too little can sound dark and dull. Try to make it clean and shiny.`````````````````````````

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: When mic’ing an acoustic, you’ll often find many of the boomy, explosive low-end tones within this range. Although a bit of it can add warmth and fullness, it will often cloud up a mix with a full band and can typically be removed with high-pass filter.

ranges.title: Body/Wood
ranges.description: Reduce at 200 Hz to remove muddiness. Boost 200-400 Hz range carefully to add more weight. Boosts here can add fullness to solo instruments but may create conflicts in a dense mix, so attenuate here if that’s the case. 200Hz - 400Hz is where the majority of the acoustic’s body lives. Be careful when working in this range, as it’s easy to flatten the tone and lose its life with too many cuts.

ranges.title: Warmth/Fullness
ranges.description: Boost 500-700Hz to add more warmth and 1kHz to bring more fullness.

ranges.title: Definition
ranges.description: The 1.5-2.5 kHz range is responsible for tiny intricacies in chords and string-picking, but boosting it too far can make guitar sound aggressive and harsh.

ranges.title: Attack/Air
ranges.description: A slight shelf boost in this range will help an acoustic sound brighter and airier. Boost around 5 kHz if more attack is needed and around 7 kHz for some additional sparkle. If it still sounds off, try boosting around 10 kHz and 12kHz spots to achieve desired result.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: Highpass 80-160 Hz to taste and use good sound design judgement.

ranges.title: Mud
ranges.description: Highpass 80-160 Hz to taste and use good sound design judgement.

ranges.title: Character
ranges.description: Most attributes of synths can be found here, so cutting or lifting certain frequencies within this range can help it to either stick out or hide away. Mix as appropriate to the individual synth / patch.

ranges.title: Presence
ranges.description: Most attributes of synths can be found here, so cutting or lifting certain frequencies within this range can help it to either stick out or hide away. Mix as appropriate to the individual synth / patch.

ranges.title: Clarity
ranges.description: Just like the guitars and vocals, you can find the exciting, airy tonal characteristics here. Boost 3-4 kHz range to add excitement and clarity. Just like the other instruments as well, too much can be shrill and unpleasant.

ranges.title: Sharpness
ranges.description: Boost the 7-9 kHz frequency range to add more sharpness and clarity, use wide Q factor.

ranges.title: Low End Rumble
ranges.description: Most sounds in this range are garbage, whether it be noise from handling the mic, vibrations from the floor or air conditioning units. Highpass up to 100-120 Hz to clean things up (note that “P” plosives reside around 90-120Hz as a general rule).

ranges.title: Mud
ranges.description: Try 3-4 dB cuts within the 325-350 Hz range on male vocals. Boost at 200 Hz can sometimes add fullness. Female vocals may run a bit higher in the spectrum, but this is a good starting point to search for boomy tones that need to be attenuated.

ranges.title: Honkiness/Nasality
ranges.description: Boosting these frequencies can help make some singer’s lyrics more intelligible. Cuts in 800-1,5 kHz range can reduce honkiness or boxiness. Use narrow Q factor.

ranges.title: Definition
ranges.description: You can add energy, buzz and definition to a vocal track right around 3 kHz. It’s important to be careful here as too much of this band can make vocals actually painful to listen to. Use with care. Try a narrow cut in the 2.5 kHz to 4 kHz range to soften vocals.

ranges.title: Clarity
ranges.description: Gentle boost in 5-10 kHz range may add extra presence to a dull vocal. Check this range for sibilance, most de-essers handle this range.

ranges.title: Air
ranges.description: To add more air do high shelf boost around 10 kHz but don’t overdo. Let your ears rest and listen to it the next day to make sure you really need it. Cuts in this range reduce the “s” sound.
